Name: Advancement in Urban Climate Modelling at Local Scale: Urban Heat Island Mitigation and Building Cooling Demand
Creator: Kubilay, A.; Allegrini, J.; Strebel, D.; Zhao, Y.; Derome, D.; Carmeliet, J.
Methodology: A framework is presented, where the urban climate is studied by coupling a meteorological model to a building-resolved local urban climate model, and where an urban climate model is coupled to a building energy simulation model. The urban climate model allows for studies at local scale, combining modelling of wind and buoyancy with computational fluid dynamics, radiative exchange and heat and mass transport in porous materials including evaporative cooling at street canyon and neighbourhood scale. This coupled model takes into account the hygrothermal behaviour of porous materials and vegetation subjected to variations of wetting, sun, wind, humidity and temperature.

Name: A comprehensive scouting of space cooling technologies in Europe: Key characteristics and development trends
Creator: Essam Elnagar, Simon Pezzutto, Bruno Duplessis, Théodore Fontenaille, Vincent Lemort
Methodology: The study aims to categorize 32 alternative space cooling technologies based on eight scouting parameters (physical energy form, basic working/operating principle, refrigerant or heat transfer medium, phase of the working fluid, specific physical process/device, type of space cooling technology, fuel type and technology readiness level) and evaluate their key characteristics and development trends.

Name: Estimation of European Union residential sector space cooling potential
Creator: Mindaugas Jakubcionis, Johan Carlsson
Methodology: A georeferenced approach was used to establish the potential residential space cooling demand in NUTS-3 regions of EU.

Name: European space cooling demands
Creator: Sven Werner
Methodology: Space cooling demands have been assessed for European service sector buildings. These estimations were based on cold deliveries from twenty different European district cooling locations in eight countries.

Name: Space Cooling Market in Europe: Assessment of the Final Energy Consumption for the Year 2016
Creator: Pezzutto, S.; Quaglini, G.; Riviere, P.; Kranzl, L.; Novelli, A.; Zambito, A.; Bottecchia, L.; Wilczynski, E.
Methodology: An extensive literature review of datasets and journal papers has been conducted to fill the knowledge gaps of the investigated energy branch.

Name: Climate change impacts on trends and extremes in future heating and cooling demands over Europe
Creator: M.A.D. Larsen, S. Petrović, A.M. Radoszynski, R. McKenna, O. Balyk
Methodology: The analysis is based on two GHG emission climate scenarios (RCP2.6 and RCP4.5) and eight high-resolution regional climate models and results are provided as relative and absolute changes on grid and country scales. Population density is used as proxy for spatial distribution of demands.

Name: Environmental Assessment of Residential Space Heating and Cooling Technologies in Europe: A Review of 11 European Member States
Creator: Fraboni, R.; Grazieschi, G.; Pezzutto, S.; Mitterrutzner, B.; Wilczynski, E.
Methodology: This article reviewed data about the environmental impact and the primary energy consumption of 27 space heating and cooling technologies for the residential sector as if they were adopted in 11 different European member states: Austria, Cyprus, Denmark, Estonia, France, Germany, Italy, Poland, Romania, Spain, and Sweden. Direct emissions from the machineries and upstream indirect emissions from the energy carriers were considered.
Geographical extension: Austria, Cyprus, Denmark, Estonia, France, Germany, Italy, Poland, Romania, Spain, and Sweden

Name: Assessment of Final Space Cooling Consumption in the European Transportation Sector
Creator: Quaglini, G.; Pezzutto, S.; Grotto, A.; Wilczynski, E.
Methodology: The fundamentals of this study include a comprehensive literature review as well as the creation of a dataset characterized by completeness and reliability. Different essential input parameters have been investigated and the encountered data and information gaps have been filled.

Name: Estimation of European Union service sector space cooling potential
Creator: Mindaugas Jakubcionis, Johan Carlsson
Methodology: A georeferenced approach based on comparing Cooling Degree Days and space cooling consumption in the USA was used to establish the potential service space cooling demand in NUTS-3 regions of EU.

Name: Assessment of the Space Heating and Cooling Market in the EU28: A Comparison between EU15 and EU13 Member States
Creator: Simon Pezzutto, Agne Toleikyte, Matteo De Felice
Methodology: Following a bottom-up approach, data of the actual space heating and cooling market are collected and analysed. Next, air-conditioning market information was retrieved through a topdown approach and compared with bottom-up acquired data.

Name: Heating and cooling energy trends and drivers in Europe
Creator: Susana Serrano, Diana Ürge-Vorsatz, Camila Barreneche, Anabel Palacios, Luisa F. Cabeza
Methodology: This paper follows the drivers identified in a previous one for the heating and cooling energy consumption, decomposing this energy demand into key drivers based on a Kaya identity approach: number of households, persons per household, floor space per capita and specific energy consumption for residential heating and cooling.

Name: Spatial Distribution of Future Demand for Space Cooling Applications and Potential of Solar Thermal Cooling Systems
Creator: Strobel, M.; Jakob, U.; Streicher, W.; Neyer, D.
Methodology: The CDMI is calculated for 2020 and 2050 in four different future scenarios in accordance with the Spatial Socioeconomic Pathways (SSP) and Representative Concentration Pathways (RCP). Further, the Solar Thermal Cooling Index (STCI) was developed to spatially estimate the worldwide potential to use solar thermal cooling systems based on solar availability and limitations due to maximum heat rejection temperature.

Name: Heat Roadmap Europe: Quantitative comparison between the electricity, heating, and cooling sectors for different European countries
Creator: D. Connolly
Methodology: Annual energy demands are compared for all 28 EU countries, while peak hourly demands are compared for four countries that vary significantly.

Name: Potential Evolution of the Cooling Market in the EU27+UK: An Outlook until 2030
Creator: Pezzutto, S.; Quaglini, G.; Zambito, A.; Novelli, A.; Riviere, P.; Kranzl, L.; Wilczynski, E.
Methodology: In this manuscript, a qualitative model—Porter’s five forces analysis (PFFA)—and a quantitative tool—multi-criteria decision analysis (MCDA)—have been applied to produce a forecast and a corresponding validation technique.

Name: Review of heating and cooling technologies for buildings: A techno-economic case study of eleven European countries
Creator: Benjamin Mitterrutzner, Claudio Zandonella Callegher, Riccardo Fraboni, Eric Wilczynski, Simon Pezzutto
Methodology: The present study develops a review of heating and cooling (H&C) technologies used to produce space H&C services in eleven European member states. On the one hand, it revises (a) technical parameters, e.g. energy efficiency, of various H&C technologies. On the other hand, it reflects the status-quo of (b) economic costs of these systems, and it exhibits a (c) short environmental impact assessment. Costs are differentiated between investment and operational costs. The H&C technology portfolio is subdivided into (i) end-use heating technologies, (ii) district heating (DH) technologies and (iii) cooling technologies.
Geographical extension: Austria, Cyprus, Denmark, Estonia, France, Germany, Italy, Poland, Romania, Spain, and Sweden

Name: Survey on the energy needs and architectural features of the EU building stock
Creator: Sarah Birchall. BSRIA, Ian Wallis, BSRIA, David Churcher, BSRIA, Simon Pezzutto, EURAC, Roberto Fedrizzi, EURAC, Emmanuelle Causse, UIPI
Methodology:
The dataset reported here is part of an extensive survey covering databases (including
Entranze, Tabula, BPIE, ODYSSEE, etc.) and single sources available in the open literature.
The full report presents information about the building stock in each country separately to the extent that information was able to be collected from public sources. All gathered data in terms of heating, cooling, Domestic Hot Water (DHW), electricity demands and
consumptions have been included into a database, which will be disclosed to the public
before spring 2015.

Name: Guiding European Policy toward a low-carbon economy. Modelling sustainable Energy system Development under Environmental and Socioeconomic constraints
Creator: Jan Blažek
Methodology:
We identify drivers and wider trends that impact future heating and cooling, incl. adaptations required at  the  energy  supply, as well as socioeconomic, technological and policy adaptations. In the
concluding section we provide suggestions for the MEDEAS model development.

Name:
Addressing Barriers for the Market Uptake of Recommended Heating and Cooling Solutions -
Heat Roadmap Europe 4
Creator: Daniel Trier, PlanEnergi, Magda Kowalska, PlanEnergi, Susana Paardekooper, Aalborg University, Jonathan Volt, BPIE, Maarten De Groote, BPIE, Aksana Krasatsenka, EHP, Dana Popp, EHP, Vincenzo Beletti, EHPA, Thomas Nowak, EHPA, Carsten Rothballer, ICLEI, George Stiff, ICLEI, Alberto Terenzi, ICLEI, Brian Vad Mathiesen, Aalborg University
Methodology: This report describes realised examples of how such barriers have already been addressed and overcome in practice and provide hints as to how these solutions can be readily replicated in other countries, including which countries seem to be in need of such solutions the most.

Name: Map of the heat synergy regions and the cost to expand district heating and cooling in all 14 MS
Creator: Urban Persson, Bernd Möller, Eva Wiechers, Lars Grundahl
Methodology: The excess heat ratio is calculated for each NUTS3 region. It is a ratio of the theoretical excess heat volume per facility/activity summarized for all facilities/activities and the total residential and service sector heat demand for space heating and domestic hot water in a given NUTS3 region.
Geographical extension: Austria, Belgium, Czech Republic, Germany, Spain, Finland, France, Hungary, Italy, Netherlands, Poland, Romania, Sweden, United Kingdom

Name: Profile of heating and cooling demand in 2015
Creator: Tobias Fleiter, Rainer Elsland, Matthias Rehfeldt, Jan Steinbach, Ulrich Reiter, Giacomo Catenazzi, Martin Jakob, Cathelijne Rutten, Robert Harmsen, Florian Dittmann, Philippe Rivière, Pascal Stabat
Methodology: The approach used combines empirical data with bottom-up modelling of energy demand. The empirical data are taken from official national statistics, surveys as well as various statistics provided e.g. by industrial organisations.

Name: Space Cooling Technology in Europe: Technology Data and Demand Modelling
Creator: Florian Dittmann, Philippe Rivière, Pascal Stabat
Methodology: The total installed capacity and overall efficiency of each technology is determined and predictions of their development up to 2050 are made using a bottom-up stock model which is based on aggregated sales data of the last 24 years from 16 EU member states.
Geographical extension:
Greece, Spain, Italy, Portugal, Romania,
France, Hungary, Austria, Czech Republic, Germany, Poland, Belgium, Netherlands, Sweden, UK, and Finland

Name: Baseline scenario of the heating and cooling demand in buildings and industry in the 14 MSs until 2050
Creator: Tobias Fleiter, Rainer Elsland, Andrea Herbst, Pia Manz, Eftim Popovski, Matthias Rehfeldt, Ulrich Reiter, Giacomo Catenazzi, Martin Jakob, Robert Harmsen, Cathelijne Rutten, Florian Dittmann, Philippe Rivière, Pascal Stabat
Methodology: This document summarizes the assumptions and definitions taken to construct the baseline scenario.
Geographical extension: Austria, Belgium, Czech Republic, Germany, Spain, Finland, France, Hungary, Italy, Netherlands, Poland, Romania, Sweden, United Kingdom

Name: FORECAST Guide for Lead Users
Creator: Tobias Fleiter, George Stiff, Ulrich Reiter
Methodology:
This guide is based on results from other deliverables including the heating and cooling profiles for
2015 (D3.1) and the baseline scenario for delivered heating and coolign demand in 2030 and 2050
(D3.3 and D3.4).

Name: Report on cost-curves for built environment and industrial energy efficiency options
Creator: Robert Harmsen, Bas van Zuijlen, Pia Manz, Tobias Fleiter, Rainer Elsland, Ulrich Reiter, Andrea Palacios, Giacomo Catenazzi, Martin Jakob
Methodology: In the optimization carried out by EnergyPLAN (WP5) a demand cost curve is used. Such curve shows the H&C demand in a specific target year which can be reduced by investing in saving measures. The larger the savings the higher the investment costs of the next unit of savings (reducing marginal utility). Both for 2030 and 2050 a cost curve will be developed.
Geographical extension: Austria, Belgium, Czech Republic, Germany, Spain, Finland, France, Hungary, Italy, Netherlands, Poland, Romania, Sweden, United Kingdom

Name: Quantifying the Impact of Low-Carbon Heating and Cooling Roadmaps
Creator:
Paardekooper, Susana; Lund, Rasmus Søgaard; Mathiesen, Brian Vad; Chang, Miguel;
Petersen, Uni Reinert; Grundahl, Lars; David, Andrei; Dahlbæk, Jonas; Kapetanakis, Ioannis
Aristeidis; Lund, Henrik; Bertelsen, Nis; Hansen, Kenneth; Drysdale, David William; Persson,
Urban
Methodology:
This HRE project is  he 4
th in a series of
analyses that combines local (geographic) data with knowledge on energy savings and detailed all sector hour-by-hour energy system analysis.
Geographical extension: Austria, Belgium, Czech Republic, Germany, Spain, Finland, France, Hungary, Italy, Netherlands, Poland, Romania, Sweden, United Kingdom

Name: WP2 Report – Open Data Set for the EU28
Creator: Simon Pezzutto, Stefano Zambotti, Silvia Croce, Pietro Zambelli, Giulia Garegnani, Chiara Scaramuzzino, Ramón Pascual Pascuas, Franziska Haas, Dagmar Exner, Elena Lucchi, Nives Della Valle, Alyona Zubaryeva (EURAC), Andreas Müller (ethink), Michael Hartner (TUW), Tobias Fleiter, Anna-Lena Klingler, Matthias Kühnbach, Pia Manz, Simon Marwitz, Matthias Rehfeldt, Jan Steinbach, Eftim Popovski
Methodology: Data has been collected at national or if available at regional/local levels. Data has been generated for four different sectors: residential (single family houses, multifamily houses, and apartment blocks), service (offices, trade, education, health, hotels and restaurants, and other non-residential buildings), industry (iron and steel, non-ferrous metals, paper and printing, non-metallic minerals, chemical industry, food, drink and tobacco, engineering and others not classified), and transport (passenger transport - public, private, rail and freight transport - heavy goods and light commercial vehicles).

Name: Heating & Cooling outlook until 2050, EU-28
Creator: Lukas Kranzl, Michael Hartner, Andreas Müller, Gustav Resch, Sara Fritz, Tobias Fleiter, Andrea Herbst, Matthias Rehfeldt, Pia Manz, Alyona Zubaryeva, Jonatan GÓMEZ VILCHEZ
Methodology:
In the Hotmaps toolbox, the comparative assessment of heating and cooling planning strategies builds
on predefined indicators like energy demand by energy carriers and end-use, share of renewable energy
sources, CO2-emissions, total costs etc.

Name: Guideline on drafting heat/cold supply contracts for small DHC systems
Creator: Linn Laurberg Jensen, Dominik Rutz, Rita Mergner, Christian Doczekal, Tomislav Pukšec, Rok Sunko, Blaž Sunko, Skupina FABRIKA, Elma Redžić, Ajla Merzić, Vladimir Gjorgievski, Ilija Batas Bjelic
Methodology: The document consists of a general introduction and overview of the national regulations on DHC supply contracts, followed by guidelines on contractual issues and examples of contracts. National regulations were collected for each country.
Geographical extension: Denmark, Germany, Austria, Slovenia, Croatia, Bosnia-Herzegovina, Serbia, Republic of Macedonia

Name: Educational e-book about MultiPACK No 1
Creator: Paride Gullo, Lorenzo Fusini, Armin Hafner
Methodology: Educational and knowledge-building promotional material presented are a direct result from the MultiPACK project activities.

Name: Educational e-book about MultiPACK No 2
Creator: Yosr Allouche, Silje Smitt, Armin Hafner
Methodology: Educational and knowledge-building promotional material presented are a direct result from the MultiPACK project activities.

Name: Moderate: Building stock analysis
Creator: Pezzutto, S and Bottino, Dario and Farahi Mohammad, Arif and Wilczynski, Eric
Methodology: Data collection has been conducted on a country-by-country basis, meticulously organized within both the residential and service sectors.

Name: Eurostat: Degree days
Creator: Statistical Office of the European Union (Eurostat)
Origin (publisher): Statistical Office of the European Union (Eurostat)
Methodology: Heating Degree Days (HDD) index:  the severity of the cold in a specific time period taking into consideration outdoor temperature and average room temperature (in other words the need for heating). The calculation of HDD relies on the base temperature, defined as the lowest daily mean air temperature not leading to indoor heating. The value of the base temperature depends in principle on several factors associated with the building and the surrounding environment. By using a general climatological approach, the base temperature is set to a constant value of 15°C in the HDD calculation. Cooling degree days (CDD) index:  the severity of the heat in a specific time period taking into consideration outdoor temperature and average room temperature (in other words the need for cooling). The calculation of CDD relies on the base temperature, defined as the highest daily mean air temperature not leading to indoor cooling. The value of the base temperature depends in principle on several factors associated with the building and the surrounding environment. By using a general climatological approach, the base temperature is set to a constant value of 24°C in the CDD calculation. For further information, see the methodology documentation.

Name: HotMaps: Building stock analysis
Creator: Simon Pezzutto, Silvia Croce, Stefano Zambotti, EURAC
Content: Building characteristics - Building surface volume ratio
Methodology: The data collected in the building stock analysis are used as starting point to calculate the useful energy demand (UED) for space heating (SH), space cooling (SC), and domestic hot water (DHW) for each EU28 MS down to its local level, and to derive scenarios for the future development of the UED.
Time reference: The majority of data refer to the year 2016

Name: Fuel consumption and technologies used in the heating/cooling sector
Creator: Authors of ENER/C2/2014-641 tender
Origin (publisher): European Commission Directorate-General for Energy (DG Energy)
Methodology: End-use energy balances for H/C for 2012: A consistent end-use energy balance is compiled for Europe’s H/C sector. The results are disaggregated by country, sector, sub-sector, building type, energy carrier end-use and temperature level. Current state of H/C technologies: This work package gathers information on the current stock of H/C technologies in European countries. It distinguishes technologies in buildings, industry and district heating and assesses the current performance of H/C technologies.
Geographical extension: EU27 + UK,  Switzerland, Norway, and Iceland

Name: IEA SHC Task 45: Large Solar Heating and Cooling Systems
Creator: Sabine Putz, S.O.L.I.D.
Origin (publisher): IEA Solar Heating and Cooling Programme
Methodology: Information was collected to create a comprehensive database of worldwide large solar heating and cooling systems has been established in Task 45.

Name: Eurostat: Renewable energy sources in heating and cooling
Creator: Statistical Office of the European Union (Eurostat)
Origin (publisher): Statistical Office of the European Union (Eurostat)
Methodology:
Data until 2020 are calculated on the basis of RED I, while data for 2021 follow RED II. Due to the change of legal basis, a break in series occurs between 2020 and 2021. Readers are encouraged to analyse the differences between both Directives (RED I and RED II), the energy sector and all national specificities before drawing any conclusions from the comparison of year 2021 with previous time series. The SHARES Manual provides details on the methodology used for the calculation of the share of renewables.

Hydro is normalised (averaged over a number of years to smooth out the effects of climatic variation) and excluding pumping. Wind is also normalised (and from 2021 onwards as per RED II separately for on-shore and off-shore). Solar includes solar photovoltaics and solar thermal power generation. All other renewables include electricity generation from gaseous and liquid biofuels, renewable municipal waste, geothermal, and tide, wave & ocean. Only electricity produced from compliant liquid biofuels can be accounted. For 2021 onwards (as per RED II), also solid and gaseous biofuels combusted in installations above a certain threshold need to comply with sustainability and greenhouse gas emissions saving criteria. Renewable energy sources used for heating and cooling include solar thermal, geothermal energy, ambient heat captured by heat pumps for heating (and from 2021 onwards, renewable cooling, as per RED II), solid, liquid and gaseous biofuels, and the renewable part of waste. Only heat produced from compliant liquid biofuels can be accounted for. From 2021 onwards (as per RED II), solid and gaseous biofuels combusted in installations above a certain threshold need to comply with sustainability and greenhouse gas emissions saving criteria. RED II modifies the multipliers for the use of renewable electricity in different means of transport.

Name: Electricity prices for household consumers
Creator: Statistical Office of the European Union (Eurostat)
Origin (publisher): Statistical Office of the European Union (Eurostat)
Methodology: Electricity prices are collected by a half-yearly questionnaire on electricity prices for households. For further information, see the methodology documentation.
Geographical extension: EU27 + UK plus Iceland, Liechtenstein, Norway, Montenegro, North Macedonia, Albania, Serbia, Turkey, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Kosovo, Moldova, Ukraine, Georgia

Name: Tropical Nights
Creator: European Environment Agency
Methodology: The data was assembled on behalf of the Copernicus Climate Change Service (C3S) based on climate projections hosted on the C3S Climate Data Store (CDS). The Index is calculated from a set of nine bias-corrected multi-model simulations from the EURO-CORDEX experiment. These simulations have a spatial resolution of 0.25° x 0.25°, a 3-hourly output, and cover scenarios RCP4.5 and RCP8.5.
Terms of use: Access to Copernicus Products is given for any purpose in so far as it is lawful, whereas use may include, but is not limited to: reproduction; distribution; communication to the public; adaptation, modification and combination with other data and information; or any combination of the foregoing.

Name: Apparent Temperature Heatwave Days
Creator: European Environment Agency
Methodology: The data was assembled on behalf of the Copernicus Climate Change Service (C3S) based on climate projections hosted on the C3S Climate Data Store (CDS). The Index data is 30-year period statistics based on a set of four bias-corrected multi-model simulations ensemble from the EURO-CORDEX experiment. These simulations have a spatial resolution of 0.1° x 0.1° and cover scenarios RCP4.5 and RCP8.5.
Terms of use: Access to Copernicus Products is given for any purpose in so far as it is lawful, whereas use may include, but is not limited to: reproduction; distribution; communication to the public; adaptation, modification and combination with other data and information; or any combination of the foregoing.

Name: Total emissions of cooling sector
Creator: Green Cooling Initiative
Methodology: The first method is a detailed calculation, based on sophisticated models using multiple predictors (generalised linear models and additive models). It is used for three appliance systems where sufficient data is available: split residential air conditioners, car air conditioners and domestic refrigerators. The second method is a simpler modelling approach based on ratios of RAC systems per inhabitants. This approach was used to determine the existing stock of ten additional appliance systems: self-contained air conditioners, commercial ducted splits, multi-splits, air conditioning chillers, mobile air conditioning in buses, stand-alone equipment (commercial refrigeration), condensing units (commercial refrigeration), centralised units in supermarkets, centralised industrial systems, and refrigerated transport. This calculated stock is then used to derive current and future unit sales figures and finally, to calculate the emissions and the potential to reduce emissions. The data shown here represents the best possible estimation based on the available data. Numbers from the two calculation approaches were combined and some individual appliance systems (such as rooftop ducted air conditioners, integral and condensing units in industrial refrigeration) could not be covered by either method due to a lack of accurate data. The figures may not fully reflect the actual situation in some countries. However, the results do give a general overview of emissions in the RAC subsectors.

Name: A bottom-up estimation of heating and cooling demand in the European industry
Creator: Matthias Rehfeldt, Clemens Rohde, Tobias Fleiter, Felipe Toro, Felix Reitze
Methodology: Eurostat’s energy balance for the industrial sector are disaggregated to including process heat temperature level and end-use.
Geographical extension: EU27 plus UK, Norway, Switzerland, Iceland

Name: Geothermal-DHC, European Research Network on Geothermal Energy in Heating and Cooling Networks
Creator: Gregor Goetzl, Dejan Milenic, Christopher Schifflechner
Methodology: The scientific focus of the network addresses the match between the different geothermal concepts and the requirements of heating (and cooling) grids from generation 2 until generation 5.

Name: An Overview of Renewable Smart District Heating and Cooling Applications with Thermal Storage in Europe
Creator: Fivos Galatoulas, Marc Frere, Christos S. Ioakimidis
Origin (publisher): Proceedings of the 7th International Conference on Smart Cities and Green ICT Systems (SMARTGREENS 2018)
Methodology: The purpose of this paper is to trace the latest advancements in existing DHC networks and to identify early smart city technologies incorporated.
Geographical extension: France, Germany, Greece, Italy, Poland, Spain, Switzerland and United Kingdom

Name: Review of the European dwelling stock and its potential for retrofit interventions using solar-assisted heating and cooling
Creator: Elguezabal, Peru; Arregi, Beñat; Schuetz, Philipp; Gwerder, Damian; Scoccia, Rossano
Methodology: After identifying relevant parameters, data has been compiled from several sources, including national statistical bodies and European datasets from official and unofficial bodies, as well as previous research projects.

Name: Review of Passive Cooling Methods for Buildings
Creator: Vaddin Chetan, Kori Nagaraj, Prakash S Kulkarni, Shiva Kumar Modi, and U N Kempaiah
Methodology: This paper aims to present a review of different types of Passive cooling technologies to reduce the cooling load on buildings.

Name: Assessment of energy savings potential and EU funding for heating and cooling
Creator: Simon Pezzutto, Wolfram Sparber, Roberto Fedrizzi
Origin (publisher): Renewable Energy World Europe Conference and Expo
Methodology: Data has been collected through literature research and analysed in order to assess the expected energy savings in the heating and cooling sector and, at the same time, to quantify the European Union´s funding for energy related researches and developments.
Geographical extension: Italy, Spain, France, Germany, Greece, Portugal

Name: Optimization of Solar District Heating & Cooling Systems
Creator: G. Brumana, G. Franchini, E. Ghirardi, and S. Ravelli
Methodology: Thermal loads are evaluated by transient simulations of a residential compound featuring 56 detached houses for three different Italian climates.

Name: Passive cooling techniques to improve resilience of nZEBs in Belgium
Creator: Alanis S. Zeoli, Vincent Lemort
Origin (publisher): CLIMA 2022 The 14th REHVA HVAC World Congress
Methodology: Passive cooling techniques are investigated through a dynamic simulation of a nearly zero-energy dwelling in Belgium. Their efficiency is assessed based on their ability to improve thermal comfort. The passive cooling techniques can be combined to ensure the resilience of the building to global warming.

Name: Potential study on demand side management in district heating and cooling networks with decentralized heat pumps
Creator: Simone Buffa, Marco Cozzini, GP Henze, Chiara Dipasquale, M Baratieri and Roberto Fedrizzi
Methodology: The scenarios presented herein compare a constant and a variable thermal network temperature control strategies adopted during the demand response program with a reference case.

Name: The Spectrum of Residential Cooling Demand: Modeled Demand Versus Occupants’ Real-life Needs
Creator: J. Mittermüller1, F. Banihashemi
Origin (publisher): BEHAVE 2020 6th European Conference on Behaviour and Energy Efficiency
Methodology: The present study introduces a bottom-up methodology and combines household-survey and thermal building simulation results in order to identify possible strategies to improve the thermal comfort while at the same time reducing or even avoiding the energy demand for active cooling.
